Legal_Issue: Whether the Citizenship Judge correctly applied the physical presence test under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Application_Facts: Applicant was absent for all but 117 days in the four-year period preceding the application
Remedy_Requested: Judicial review of Citizenship Judge's decision
Court_Ruling: Citizenship Judge did not err in applying the physical presence test
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to meet required 1,095 days of physical presence
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged incorrect application of residency test by Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard: Literal physical presence required under s. 5(1)(c)
Assessment_Factor: Number of days physically present in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Judicial review under s. 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Record of applicant's physical presence/absence over four-year period
Application_Basis: Requirement to accumulate 1,095 days of residence in four years
Evidence_Assessed: Duration and pattern of applicant's physical presence in Canada
Governing_Rule: Physical presence test requires literal presence; qualitative approach not applicable
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Applicant fell short by 978 days of required residency
Outcome: Appeal dismissed; applicant remains ineligible for citizenship
Harm_Assessment: No harm due to lawful enforcement of statutory requirement
Cause_Description: Applicant's failure to meet residency requirements under s. 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Handling: Objective assessment of days of physical presence based on official records
Residency_Compliance: Non-compliant â€“ only 117 days of presence out of 1,095 required
Evidence_Assessment: Days of absence clearly documented; no dispute over factual record
Decision_Rationale: Statutory interpretation mandates literal physical presence; qualitative factors not permitted
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Legal_Standard_Applied: Statutory interpretation favoring literal meaning of physical presence
